title: Angular impulse - rotating bar collides with disk

content.question: A bar of length <math alttext="lowercase l sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mo>ℓ</mo><mtext>B</mtext></msub></math> is on a horizontal tabletop and is free to rotate about a fixed vertical pivot at one end, as shown in the figures. The rotational inertia of the bar about the pivot is <math alttext="I sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></math>. The bar rotates in the counterclockwise direction with initial angular velocity <math alttext="omega sub i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></math> before its free end collides with a small, stationary disk of mass <math alttext="m sub D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>D</mtext></msub></math>. After the collision, the bar continues to rotate in the counterclockwise direction with angular velocity <math alttext="omega sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></math>, and the disk moves forward with translational velocity <math alttext="v sub D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>D</mtext></msub></math>. All frictional forces are negligible, and the disk is much smaller in size than <math alttext="lowercase l sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mo>ℓ</mo><mtext>B</mtext></msub></math>. With respect to the pivot, what is the magnitude of the angular impulse exerted on the bar during the collision?
